qas.question: In what decade did sociologists focus on the social relevance of emotion?
What emotions did Cooley regard as of paramount social importance?
Who studied rage and shame cycles in married couples?
Who developed the social bond theory?
Along with Cooley, from whose work did Scheff derive social bond theory?
In what decade didn't sociologists focus on the social relevance of emotion?
What emotions didn't Cooley regard as of paramount social importance?
Who studied rage and shame cycles in un-married couples?
Who rejected the social bond theory?
Along with Cooley, from whose work did Scheff not derive social bond theory?

context: In the <a0_0><b5_0>1990s<b5_0/><a0_0/>, sociologists focused on different aspects of specific emotions and how these emotions were socially relevant. For Cooley (1992), <a1_0><b6_0>pride and shame<b6_0/><a1_0/> were the most important emotions that drive people to take various social actions. During every encounter, he proposed that we monitor ourselves through the "looking glass" that the gestures and reactions of others provide. Depending on these reactions, we either experience pride or shame and this results in particular paths of action. <a2_0><b7_0>Retzinger<b7_0/><a2_0/> (1991) conducted studies of married couples who experienced cycles of rage and shame. Drawing predominantly on <a4_0><b9_0>Goffman<b9_0/><a4_0/> and Cooley's work, <a3_0><b8_0>Scheff<b8_0/><a3_0/> (1990) developed a micro sociological theory of the social bond. The formation or disruption of social bonds is dependent on the emotions that people experience during interactions.
